Obviously, my expectation for a Disney Channel Original Movie was not that high but then again look at how well High School Musical took off (even with the rocky dialogue in the first film). I couldn't wait to see this new perspective on some of Disney's most infamous villains and I have to say this completely exceeded my expectations. The music, choreography, and actors are all phenomenal. Honestly, my favorite part though is all of the costuming and accessories. It is a total blast to look at other characters and guess their origin character by the costumes. Every time you watch it there is something new to notice. I'm not saying it has the most believable plotline (there are definitely some flaws) but it is definitely an empowering Disney Channel movie that tells us we are responsible for our actions and no one else. We decide. It's definitely a lesson I want my kids to learn. And as Mal so kindly hinted that we would be seeing more of them......I cannot wait!

This movie is perhaps the worst Disney movie I've ever seen. The plotline is trite, and over done. I swear I lost brain cells just watching it. The lipsynching is terrible, and the songs are just mediocre at best. The only reason I didn't give it less stars is because Amazon won't let you give zero stars, the choreographed scenes are actually really decent, and the actors ARE talented. Overall, a waste of time, money, and good talent.

Honestly, what I think upsets me most about this movie is the fact that it could have been good. It had the potential to be a decent movie, it really did. There was a good premise. "What happens when the children of Disney villains meet and socialize with the children of those their parents tried to destroy?" But they tried to shove so many freaking plot points into one movie. "Love conquers all", "Don't judge someone based on their looks", "Good always wins in the end", "Get the fairy godmother wand to free your parents that you fear", "We were never shown love as children and were abused regularly, but we still love our parents even though we have no reason to", "magic has been retired in the name of technology" (I really, REALLY, hate this plot point. It's such a cop out for a FANTASY based plot) just to name a few.  With everything they try and shove in your face it just winds up coming across as rushed, murky, and forced.

They treat the villains (the Disney classic villains) as the butt of a joke. The children are supposed to be afraid of them, but I don't understand how anyone can find them more than washed up wannabes that couldn't fill a thimble with their menace. THESE ARE CLASSIC VILLAINS, and they're reduced to that old high school jock at the bar. You know the one. That one that complains that he could've been the big cheese and gotten out of that Podunk town he lives in, if only he hadn't of blown out his knee cap in the last quarter of the "big game". So, he sits at the bar, refusing to move on with his life and make something more of himself, and regales tales of "the good old days" to anyone who will listen. Which is unforgivable, considering the actors they had behind them have more talent than that and the villains themselves are A rank in the Disney universe.

Now onto the kids. While the actors are talented and you can tell they're really trying to make a crap sandwich look appetizing, there's no real reason for them to act the way they do. Half of the cast has no purpose (the romantic rival is barely worth batting an eye at). And the chemistry between the main couple is forced, at best. They have no reason to be afraid of their parents once they leave the island. NONE. They even acknowledge that there's no way for them to reach the children. The hatred of the "good guys" children towards the "bad guys" children is ridiculous and makes the good guys look terrible. What kind of message are they trying to send here? It's ok to hate on someone who had no choice in regards to their parent? Yea. That seems totally reasonable *eye roll*. Sins of the father and all. And it's not even like they truly resolve this plot point either. You think saving a hardcore bigot's life is going to change the mind of said bigot in the blink of an eye? NO. Not when said bigot has literally been raised from birth to hate your parent and by default you. That kind of indoctrination doesn't just dissapear over night. They could've made an effort to at least show that the dunderhead was going through their own change in perception through the course of the movie, but no. That's to much effort.

The nitty gritty of the whole mess: Ramshackle plot slapped together with more loose ends than your grandmothers sewing basket, made for the sole purpose of cashing in on childhood nostalgia. Villains are trash. Story is trash. If you're looking for that Disney magic, you won't find it here, look some where else.

This is "very Disney" - but also fun. What happens to Disney's villains and heroes when they grow up and live "happily ever after"? Are the villains' kids just as evil as their parents? In an experiment, when the son of Belle & the Beast is made king at 18, he decrees that they're going to bring over four kids from "the Isle" (the magically enchanted island that keeps villains prisoner) to Auradon Prep, to show them that there's a different way of life than living "evilly".

The kids brought over are the daughters of Maleficent and the Evil Queen from Snow White, and the sons of Cruella de Ville and Jafar. The movie skillfully portrays the pressure the kids feel to live up to their parents' expectations, especially Mal, who is being pressured by her mother, Maleficent (oh, it is delicious to see Kristin Chenoweth playing evil for a change!), to find a spellbook and a wand that will free The Isle from its prison status. Can the "Kids from the Isle" prove that what's inside can triumph over their upbringing? Well - this is Disney, so what do you think? ;)

I got this for myself (at 44) when Amazon was running a $0.99 special on the rental, and I liked it.  The first five or so minutes had me regretting my purchase because it seemed like a childish made-for-TV movie, and I thought it would really only appeal to younger kids.  However, as the movie went on, it became more appealing to me.  It is a good movie for kids as there is no "adult" content or anything inappropriate, but it became much less "childish" after the first few minutes and I think it will appeal to adults, too.

I like Disney movies and cartoons, and I thought it was a cool idea to have a show about the kids of characters that I've watched over the years.  It's a fun show.  It's not a highly polished movie with top-tier actors, but the younger actors in this are certainly talented.  They act over the top at times, but I think that's just because that's what the movie called for.

I'd recommend it as a nice movie for the family or just for yourself (perhaps on a lazy weekend).

When my sister's DVR died and she had to get a new one from the cable company, my 7-year-old niece's only concern was losing the copy of "Descendants" they had recorded. I bought this disc to replace the lost digital copy and to give her something to watch in the car on longer trips -- and it has been played almost as many times as the digital copy.

The basic story is "new classic" Disney; moral lessons presented in a highly entertaining manner, with surprisingly good acting and some musical numbers that I actually don't mind getting caught in my head from time to time. Although pitched to young "tweens," Descendants is written and performed well enough to remain entertaining for adults -- a good thing, since my niece has had me (and/or her other grownups) watch it literally several dozen times in its entirety, plus still keeps "Rotten to the Core" in her iTunes playlist.

While my niece enjoys the dancing, music, and fun of living in a magic land, her grownups like the fact that there are some very simple, basic morals being presented both religion-free AND in a non-cookie-cutter manner. Not only is it made obvious why being good is better than being bad, it's also shown that being too full of yourself is not good; that assuming superiority because you're "good" instead of "bad" can lead "bad guys" being better people in general; that judging people without knowing them, based on what other people have done, can lead to wrong assumptions; that it's a good thing to remain true to yourself AND be part of a larger group; and that every person has their own set of talents and capabilities that they should embrace and not bury just to be popular (or to hook up with the popular kids).

I admit that I got the idea to watch the first Disney Descendants film after unexpectedly catching the tail end of the Descendants 2 film less than 4 hours ago and deciding by one of the dragon scenes of this film to check out the first Descendants. Additionally, curiosity influenced me  enough to watch it as both an aspiring writer for plot ideas on connecting this series to Ever After High and simply just to watch it as a fantasy type film with a happy ending.  The Descendants film involves a plot where Ben (Mitchell Hope) successfully convinces his parents who are now queen and king of the land of Auradon Belle (Keegan Connor Tracy) and Beast (Dan Payne) to allow the following children into Auradon Prep School;Mal (Dove Cameron) daughter of Malificent (Kristin Chenoweth has featured in such films as 12 Men of Christmas, Tinker Bell and the Lost Treasure), Evie (Sofia Carson) daughter of the Evil Queen (Kathy Najimy),Carlos (Cameron Boyce) son of Cruella de Vil (Wendy Raquel Robinson), and Jay (Booboo Stewart) son of Jaffar (Maz Jobrani). Of course, there are multiple actors and actresses who also play crucial roles into the plot. From what I see, the Descendants film sends a healthy and positive (maybe even spiritual message) that it is possible for a person to create their own happy reality that is different from what may be expected of them depending on their parental andor family background. Obviously, this lesson could still be inclusive depending on whether what type of background a person came from. The children of the villains do adjust to life really well at Auradon Prep school and even enjoy themselves. This Descendants film is also good if you enjoy musical movies as there are song performances in the film.  I may be in the minority saying this, yet I do feel that the writers of the Ever After High Series and the Descendants films could maybe get together and collaborate (as there are creative parallels in a beneficial way with  some of the plot points while each of the series maintains its own originality). I also know for sure that I intend to eventually purchase both Disney Descendants films.

Entertaining, original, and fun concept that crashes and burns at the end.  About halfway through,  the off-kilter movie you have been watching is replaced with sterile dreck.  It is like two different writers were employed,  one with considerable imagination was assigned to the first half,  and one totally lacking in originality to the second - then the two halves were taped together with little effort to sand down the incongruities.

It still works quite effectively as a Dove Cameron promotional vehicle.  She absolutely glows on the screen,  your eyes are drawn to her in any wide group shot.  Her kinky look (for Disney purple hair & gothish outfits are kinky) agrees with her and amps up her hotness, as does her character's "disdainful youth" thing.  Of course it doesn't hurt that none of the other actresses are remotely as beautiful;  I doubt that this was an accident.  The production begins its downward slide the first time Cameron puts on a conventional outfit.

Melanie Paxson's Fairy Godmother was hilarious even as the film was falling apart around her.  She seems to be channeling Daniella Monet's Trina Vega persona,  think Trina auditioning to play an older character in a Hollywood Arts production.

They could have really had something special here,  but at least the first half is well worth your time.  And it nicely reveals that Cameron is no light weight and should be seeking out bad girl roles and overplayed original stuff like her "Froyo" music video.  Her talents are wasted on much of the sterile stuff Disney has thrown her way.

Then again, what do I know?  I'm only a child.

Our kids love this movie, we've watched the DVD several times and I'm sure we'll watch it several more. The thing I like about "Disney's Descendants" is that it reminds me so much of the fantasy musicals our family loved from the past, films like "Mary Poppins" and "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory". It's probably more like the 2003 musical "Wicked" or 1978's "The Wiz" than the original "The Wizard of Oz" with Judy Garland, because it's a new twist on a classic, but what I personally like about it is what that it's "not" trying to be the dark and serious or type of fairy tale movie that's become so common lately.

It's old fashioned Walt Disney fun with some pretty cool modern music. It's maybe a little goofier than it needs to be in some places, but this made for TV movie's special effects are pretty impressive, the sets and costumes are great, and the young cast are so smart and talented, acting, singing, and dancing like pros, that I enjoy seeing "Descendant" more and more each times the kids want to see it again. Our family hopes there will be a sequel or two if this what we can look forward too, the kind of Fantasy-Musical-Comedy that the Walt Disney Co. was built on

Do not make the mistake of relegating the artistic merits of this movie to those of just "family movies" or "kids films". It is a movie. Hold it to the very same standards as you would for any movie at all. Especially for something you would show your kids.

I love Disney. It is a fantastic, successful company that makes quality products in nearly every area it has a market in. But any creative executives at the firm should be relatively ashamed to have their name on this.

The worst crime that the movie committed is the main character, and the message. The main character is Mal, the daughter of Maleficent. (Maleficent is extremely out of character in the movie, by the way. And isn't even green.) At the beginning of the film through the second act, she is actually a fairly likeable, respectable character that I enjoyed from an objective critical standpoint. In the prince/princess prep school environment of prissiness and good behavior, Mal is not intrepid to openly express her more rebellious attitude, alternative style, and her artistic side. This is extremely unique, defiant, likeable and admirable in a character in this type of an environment. Especially for kids. The movie stresses that it's message is to be yourself and never shy away from who you are. But in the third act, the Mal character abandons her entire personality and even dons a pretty-princess dress--completely assimilating into the adverse, even villainized, boring, well-behaved, prim-and-proper culture of the other students at the school. So sure, kids! Be yourself! But only if you wise up and be like everyone else in the end. That's the only way you'll find true love and be accepted by society. That is a hypocritical, garbage message, and a wasted opportunity to do something original with a unique main character. But it doesn't stop there.

Another character, Carlos, is the son of Cruella DeVile. He has a strange, irrational fear of dogs for some reason that serves no purpose to the plot. (Cruella DeVile hated dogs, she wasn't afraid of them. It doesn't make any sense that her son would fear dogs. It's just a poor excuse to try and be cute. There is no negative sentiment about dogs amongst society. We do not need to be shown that dogs are okay.)  Carlos is depicted as being poor at sports. When he does not do well on his try-outs for lacrosse, the coach says something to the effect of "You ever think about band?" in a very diminutive, mean-spirited fashion. This is insulting on so many levels. First of all, what this is telling your kids, (if you are dumb enough to show this rotten movie to them), is that sports are to be valued more than music, and that if you don't have athletic talent, you should feel bad. Hurtful, untrue, and insulting to people and kids who love music. I was in band in highschool. We were the biggest group/club/team in the whole school! Besides, if you're telling kids that music is for losers, than who's going to make all of that music that you like putting in your high-school-wannabe-teen tv movies, hm?

That's the next offense. The music. When Disney churned out High School Musical, they knew very quickly that they struck gold. HSM is original, enjoyable, and artistic compared to Descendants. It is insultingly obvious that the movie is trying to use the same pop song with dance choreography in a high school setting AGAIN in an attempt to bolster kids attention and the films success. Even worse, they blatantly rip off entirely accapella vocals and pop song and dance choreography in a high school setting for an entire number. (Glee, anyone!) The worst of the bunch is a mutilated, bastardized, hip-hop version of Be Our Guest from Beauty and the Beast. It's not cute. It's not fun. It's not creative. It comes off as disingenuous, half-assed, and phoned in.

The film also has a lot of logical fallacies, plot holes, insulting stereotypes, and even things that contradict Disney's own history! The ethnicities of some of the characters is was a big issue for me. Now, I am ALL for ethnic diversity, especially in a kids film. But you HAVE to do it in a way that makes sense. Kids aren't dumb. They may not vocalize it all the time, but they notice when something doesn't add up. Why is Cruella DeVille African American? Kids have seen 101  dalmations! They know she's a white, French woman. You even kept her white in the live action movie! Why change it now? Just poor casting? No. It's the films illogical way of trying to racially diversify a movie that is whiter than a snowstorm in a way that goes against Kid-known Disney history. Why didn't they just choose an African American main character, or supporting character? Also, the character Jay, the son of Jafar, (Saudi Arabian), doesn't look Middle Eastern in the least. At all. Furthermore, Jafar is depicted as an Epcot Arabia, stereotypical, morrocan/sikh/caricature. Why didn't they keep the costume from Aladdin? They didn't even TRY to recreate it! The worst part, though, is Mulan's daughter. Oh my god, they way they show her initially is like a klansman from Kentucky's idea of what a Chinese woman would look like. But get this! She only finds herself pretty when she has Mal magically change her hair to a wavy, longer, European hairstyle. What a great lesson for kids! "White aesthetics are the only pretty ones!" "You only look good if you look like you're from a french fairy tale! Abandon your culture, traditions, and heritages!". There's also just a bunch of things that don't make sense, or are just in bad taste. There are literally infant mortality jokes in a classroom setting in the middle of the movie. Yeah. Sure. Show your kids that.

I don't know, folks... It may sound like I'm nitpicking, but I'm really not. Every film has flaws, but in a good film, you don't notice those flaws the first time you watch it. These were blaring, obvious, nasty, mean-spirited, illogical, and unoriginal. There ARE good films for kids that are just good films over all. Films like Secret Of Nimh, Spirited Away, Song Of The Sea, and a bunch of other movies for kids literally do hold up even until adulthood as masterful pieces of cinema. Don't just settle for what's popular, or what you think will sedate your kids for a while. You could be harming their worldview, mentalities, or worst of all, their creativity by showing them this awful, uninspired, hypocritical wank of a movie, and contemporaries thereof.

P.S. The biggest injustice this movie commits is insulting the title of the wonderful George Cloony movie of the same name about family landownership, and geographic torist development in hawaii.

Unlike previous Disney movies, Descendants opens up with a story from a tablet instead of a book.  When Belle and Beast married they rounded up all of the villains and cast them away on an island with no Wifi and no escape.  That is until Belle and Beast's son, Ben, is crowned king of Auradon and gives the offspring of the most notorious villains a chance to live a normal life in his kingdom.  Their parents Evil Queen (Snow White), Maleficent (Sleeping Beauty), Jafar (Aladdin), and Cruella De Vil (101 Dalmations) eagerly await their kids efforts to reclaim the fairy godmother's wand to undo the protection magic on the Isle of the Lost.

Getting their hands on the wand is no easy task since it is locked down in a museum.  The misfits will have to make friends at the boarding school and become acquainted with the offspring of Dopey, Cinderella, Sleeping Beauty, Mulan, and the fairy godmother.  Sadly many of the friendships are one sided as the descendants are using their social engineering skills and magic to get what they want.

They're not all bad once they step away from their parent's shadows though.  I like how this movie teaches about forgiveness and redemption.  Each of the descendants learns to accomplish things on their own and they become well aware of good and evil and its consequences.  Some of the treatment the descendants get is well deserved, but not all of it is.

Without spoiling the story I'll refrain from going into more detail.  I do however, highly recommend this film for anyone who enjoys Disney's animated classics.  The characters are well developed and the songs (though obviously lip synched) and costumes are vibrant and well done.  I enjoyed the rap remake of Be Our Guest.  All three of my kids liked this film and  I'm sure other families will enjoy it as well.

Honestly I think I liked this movie more than my kids. Granted my boys are 7 and 8 and don't really care about fairy tales and my daughter is only 4, I really liked the characters and story. It is such a cute story featuring four villains whose kids were chosen by Beauty and the Beast's son, the prince, to come to high school with all the good kids. The villains live on their own island and you can imagine what it looks like with all the villains and troublemakers living there, especially compared to where all the goody-goody people live. The villain teenagers don't want to go but their overbearing parents of course want them to go and steal something that would allow them to take over. Will the teenagers make their parents proud and be bad or will they make their own decisions? It is such a great story for today's kids of how kids can make their own decisions rather than following in their parent's footsteps. I've known friends who were miserable because they did what their parents wanted them to do/be rather than hurt their feelings and say they don't want to. My own kids have done that and I've had to explain it is okay to be different. For example, my husband is huge into hockey and got our boys into it. They played it but I could tell my middle child just didn't want to do it but was doing it because his dad wanted him to.

When I first heard about this movie, I had no expectations (haven't had any for a Disney Channel Movie since the disappointment that was Halloweentown High and then the travesty that was Return to Halloweentown). It peaked my interest slightly when I read Kathy Najimy was playing the Evil Queen but then lowered when I read Kristin Chenoweth was playing Maleficent (good actress/singer but not the person who I imagine playing someone who's the worst of the worst). I also figured how this movie would play out when I saw the basic plot and it ended how I expected (though I wasn't expecting the High School Musical finale rip-off). Wanting my pain to end, I watched the movie on the Watch Disney Channel app the night before the premiere and... boy was I right! I had nothing good to say about this movie; everything was wrong from casting to the fact that it was a musical.

First the songs. These were some of the most insipid, lazily written songs for a Disney film featuring classic Disney characters. With the exception of Rotten to the Core and Evil Like Me, they all sound like rejects/leftovers from High School Musical. Evil Like Me, while not great, is probably the best of the bunch since it sounds like a classic Disney song. Which is more than I can say for the one classic that is in the film which sounds terrible! Excluding the aforementioned song, they all sound the same and all the actors are auto-tuned like crazy.

Now the teen (early twenties) actors. The heroes I was fine with, they played their bland, stereotypical high school roles. But the villains' kids were the disappointment except Booboo Stewart as Jay.  These are the kids of Disney's vilest villains? Is this a joke? I never bought these kids as evil, they all came across as nice, particularly Dove Cameron as Mal. She pouted her lip for a good chunk of the time but I never believed that she was the daughter of Disney's most powerful villain. Her acts of evil border on the misdemeanor (especially the clichd "stealing candy from a baby" schtick). I know they're teenagers but since they're supposed to be the offspring of Disney's worst (you know, like cursing a baby to die because you weren't invited to her christening, wanting a young girls' heart ripped out because she's prettier than you, stealing and wanting to kill 99 puppies to make a coat, and hypnotizing the ruler of a nation while making his daughter your personal slave), I expect more than messing up someone's hair.

Which brings me to my next point: the parents. Good God Disney Channel, what did you do? There is no way these characters are the same ones who were capable of the crimes I listed above. The Evil Queen and Maleficent were cold and calculating, Cruella de Vil and Jafar were psychotics. Here we have Kathy Najimy with her face pulled back (but at least her vanity remained), Jafar is a junk salesman for no reason and Cruella seems like a drugged out loon and didn't even resemble her own character (keep in mind I'm not talking about Wendy Raquel Robinson herself but the fact that she doesn't have the black and white hair or her big fur coat while Kathy Najimy's Evil Queen retains her original costume and Maz Jobrani's Jafar at least had a red turban). But it's Kristin Chenoweth's Maleficent who barely resembles her former self. No longer the demanding presence she was in Sleeping Beauty, Once Upon A Time or her own crappy film, here she's more reminiscent of Bette Midler's Winifred Sanderson or MMPR's Rita Repulsa; over the top and chewing the scenery. The scene in the Hall of Villains (where at least the four resemble their past selves) is where I face palmed when the Mistress of All Evil starts singing and dancing. Now I'm a fan of villain songs; I love Poor Unfortunate Souls, Be Prepared, Hellfire, Friends on the Other Side and Mother Knows Best and I know the only reason she gets a song is because they realized "Hey, we got Kristin Chenoweth, let's give her a song!" but Maleficent, along with the Evil Queen and Cruella, are villains who don't need to sing a song to convey how evil they are, they just do what they do. In fact the song would've been better suited for Ursula or Mother Gothel, who are overly dramatic, give sass, and crack jokes as they sing. But I'll admit they did get a few things right by having Maleficent be evil (a sillier, non-threatening evil), teleport about AND turn into a dragon (more than that crappy live action film did anyway)

There is one scene I do like. It's small and I'm probably putting too much into this but I liked it. When Queen Leah (Aurora's mother) berates Mal for what her mother did to her daughter and how she felt, knowing she missed her child growing up. It made me notice that there was something sadly missing from this movie: actual conflict. It was actually great to see someone challenging the Prince's proclamation on allowing the villains' kids into the kingdom. Of course this leads to the oh-so-obvious moral at the end but it's something I wish there was more of. Not the snide little comments between Mal and Audrey or trying to put Prince Ben under a love spell, but repercussions for how the villains affected the lives of the people they hurt. Granted I don't know how'd they do that with Cruella since her story didn't deal with royals or anything but whatever, just a small scene that was more powerful than Mal singing and flailing her arms about while scenes we just saw fifteen seconds ago flash across the screen.

Somewhere there was a good movie trying to come out. If there were different actors or no songs, this would've had something going for it. Not asking for a gripping character study on the psychology of villains but just something that doesn't insult the legacy of these characters. I'm hoping there won't be a sequel but judging from that ending, there probably will.

Ive been hearing for months about the new Disney Channel movie Descendants.  I thought it sounded like a lot of fun, and Ive was really looking forward to its premier last Friday night.  Wow, was it disappointing.

The movie tells the story of Mal (Dove Cameron), Carlos (Cameron Boyce), Jay (Booboo Stewart), and Evie (Sofia Carson), the kids of Maleficent (Kristin Chenoweth), Cruella de Vil (Wendy Raquel Robinson), Jafar (Maz Jobrani), and Evil Queen (Kathy Najimy) respectively.  Because their parents have been banished to the Isle of the Lost, theyve grown up there and never seen the rest of the kingdom.

However, Prince Ben (Mitchell Hope) is about to take the throne of the united kingdom of Auradon, and he wants to give these kids of villains a chance to prove they can be good.  Hes selected these four as the first batch to come and go to school, sometimes with the kids of the very people their own parents tried to harm.

But Maleficent has a plan of her own.  If these four kids can just get the Fairy Godmothers (Malanie Paxson) wand, then their parents can escape the island and get their ultimate revenge.  Will the kids be able to get the wand?

Now lets dispel the idea that I was upset by this film being predictable.  Yes, it went where I expected it to go, but that was fine.  I don't mind predictable  if I am enjoying the film.  It was the rest that went wrong.

For one thing, there are too many characters.  I mean, look at the list of characters I mentioned above, and thats just the start.  Each of the descendants have their own sub-plot of character growth, but they aren't developed enough for us to care.  The only one that comes close is Mal, and thats because she is really our main character.  They should have axed the other three and just really focused on her.  As it is, I never got to know the characters enough to care about the outcome.

Then theres the acting.  Mitchell Hope, Dove Cameron, and Kristin Chenoweth were all fine, but the rest of the cast hammed it up.  This is especially true of the adult villains, who didn't feel like the villains we already love to hate at all.  Now, if you check out my reviews, youll quickly see that I can get into cheesy and corny acting and really enjoy it.  Here, it was just painful.

Once Kenny Ortega of High School Musical and Newsies fame was attached to direct, this movie turned into a musical.  The songs weren't bad, but they didn't really add much to the film.  If that screen time had been spent on character development, the movie would have been better.

Really, it just comes down to character development.  We don't know the characters enough to care about the outcome we know is coming, so we are bored waiting for the film to get there.

I had such high hopes for Descendant, but the film just couldn't meet them.  I won't be wasting my time on it again in the future.

*THE FOLLOWING REVIEW CONTAINS MINOR SPOILERS* First off, before I get into the review, this film is a sequel to Melissa De La Cruz's The Isle of the Lost: A Descendants Novel (The Descendants), a story about four children, Mal, Evie, Carlos, and Jay, who are the offspring of Disney's greatest villains--Malificent, The Evil Queen, Cruella, and Jafar. Without spoiling too much the plot revolves around them questioning their parents moral decisions and whether or not they should follow in their footsteps. I haven't read the book but when I heard about it (and the film) my heart was pumping in anticipation. ...I really, really wanted to like this movie. As a longtime Disney nerd there was so much wasted potential here. The story more or less is the standard DCOM fare. Now I am a sucker for this and if done right the film could be great, but sadly the story ultimately fell flat for a variety of reasons, the first being the pacing. Unfortunately most of the screentime was focused on Mal. While not necessarily a bad thing, Evie, Jay, and Carlos are kind of just there and lacked substance. They all get their little 'moment' to prove they play some part but ultimately it felt forced trying to cram all these subplots into such a short amount of time. Development for those three as characters was thrown under the bus. We don't know enough about them to care. Had Mal been the only main character I believe the overall story wouldn't have felt so rushed, which leads me into my next point: the love-story aspect between Mal and another character (I won't spoil it). This was a totally unnecessary subplot for the movie; the villains' development as people from evil to good is far more than enough. As cute as the couple looks this plot was just very poorly executed. It didn't help that the two leading actors had zero chemistry together. Ultimately this wasted screentime that could have been spent elsewhere. Character execution for the overall cast was very weakly handled. The other characters include Ben (Belle's son), Audrey (Sleeping Beauty's daughter), Chad (Cinderella's son), with Lonnie (Mulan's daughter), Doug (Dopey's son--a totally random and completely unnecessary character), and Jane (Fairy Godmother's daughter) popping in every now and them. Excluding Ben, who is courageous and kind and gives the villains a chance to redeem themselves in the first place, what surprised me was how shallow the rest of these characters were. As the offspring of their benevolent parents you would think they'd be good-natured and fair! Chad flirts with Evie just so she'd do his homework for him and then ditches her to be with another girl. Audrey was the typical popular beauty queen who had Ben wrapped around her little bratty finger, wining and complaining about everything Ben said or did, dying to be the center of attention among her peers and showing no remorse when belittling others to do so. And at the end of the film one of these characters performs this totally random 'out-of-the-blue' twist that is very unlike them, making me believe Disney just randomly threw it in hoping to achieve a 'wow' factor. And the villains' parents themselves? Malificent, Jafar, Cruella and The Evil Queen were presented as bumbling idiots, totally out of character from their malicious animated film counterparts. I was not impressed. Production values were solid overall. The music and costumes were decent, as was the acting. Kristin Chenoweth killed it as Malificent and up-and-coming Disney star Dove Cameron and Mitchell Hope stole the show as Mal and Ben. Cameron and Booboo seemed to be enjoying themselves as the eccentric Carlos and Jay respectively and Sofia Carson looked stunning as Evie. Directed and choreographed by the famous Kenny Ortega (High School Musical), the film features a plethora of well-versed song-and-dance numbers. Ortega's strength is creating these dance numbers and it clearly shows here. The songs themselves were just 'okay' to horribly cringe worthy, especially the first song "Rotten to the Core," and "Be Our Guest," a modern remix of Howard Ashman/Alan Menken's song written for the 1991 animated version of Beauty and the Beast. If Ashman were alive he would be ashamed at this horrendous butchering of his work. Disney ripped apart a classic song and turned it into goodness knows what. The kids of this generation will love it but as an old-timer I felt it was an insult to their legacy. Otherwise, "If Only" was a nice little ballad and "Set it Off" was a strong finisher in wrapping up the film's core values--we are not who are parents--or others for that matter--define us. I had high hopes for the music overall coming from the acclaimed Ortega but these songs weren't doing it for me. The music is not one of his better efforts and in my opinion it marks one of his weakest score to date. Despite all my complaints, the movie still carries good messages for children and is certainly age appropriate for young audiences. All in all Descendants had the potential to be phenomenal had certain plot-lines been executed differently, had there been better music, had there been more screen time for other characters, and had there been changes to the overall story. I'd definitely recommend the film for small children--they will love it--but adult audiences looking for more will not be satisfied. 2.8/5
